title: Penetrating Thoracic Trauma with Hemothorax
diagnosis_topic: Gunshot wound causing massive hemothorax and potential cardiac injury
setup_script: “A 29-year-old man presents with a single gunshot wound to the left posterior chest. He is short of breath and coughing up blood. He has no past medical history. On arrival, he appears distressed. How would you proceed with this patient?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident assesses airway and breathing
dynamic_flow.reply: Airway is patent. Breath sounds are decreased on the left with dullness to percussion.
BP 95/55 mmHg, HR 125 bpm, RR 28/min, SpO₂ 90% on a nonrebreather mask.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident establishes IV access and orders labs/type and cross
dynamic_flow.reply: Two large-bore IVs placed, blood sent. Initial hemoglobin 10 g/dL, INR 1.2.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident places a large-bore chest tube on the left
dynamic_flow.reply: 1.5 L of blood drains immediately, followed by continuous output > 200 mL/hr.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders chest X-ray after tube placement
dynamic_flow.reply: Film shows left hemothorax decompressed, chest tube in good position, mediastinum shifted toward the right.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates blood transfusion and resuscitation
dynamic_flow.reply: Two units PRBCs given. HR improves to 110, BP to 100/60, SpO₂ 94% on nonrebreather. Chest tube continues to drain > 200 mL/hr.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about indications for thoracotomy
dynamic_flow.reply: Chest tube output > 1500 mL initially or > 200 mL/hr ongoing suggests major vascular injury.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident prepares for operative intervention
dynamic_flow.reply: Trauma and cardiothoracic surgery teams are mobilized for emergent thoracotomy.
Patient becomes hypotensive to 70/40 mmHg, HR 140, and progresses to cardiac arrest.
A left posterolateral thoracotomy is performed. There is massive intrathoracic clot and active bleeding from the left pulmonary hilum.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident is asked to describe operative steps
dynamic_flow.reply: Please describe your operative approach, exposure, hemorrhage control, and repair options for this injury.
There is pulmonary parenchymal injury with bleeding from segmental vessels, and concern for cardiac injury near the pericardium.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident performs appropriate repair or clamping
dynamic_flow.reply: Hemorrhage is controlled, BP improves to 100/65, HR decreases to 110.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident discusses intraoperative adjuncts (packing, cross-clamping aorta, autotransfusion)
dynamic_flow.reply: Autotransfusion is available; patient receives additional resuscitation and stabilizes.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about postoperative course
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient is transferred to ICU intubated, on vasopressors. Risks include retained hemothorax, empyema, ARDS, and recurrent bleeding.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident addresses postoperative pain control
dynamic_flow.reply: IV analgesia provided; patient remains sedated and ventilated in ICU.

critical_decision_points: Management of airway, breathing, and circulation in penetrating chest trauma
Recognition of massive hemothorax and indications for thoracotomy
Timely chest tube placement and monitoring of output
Activation of operative team without unnecessary delay
Intraoperative control of bleeding and repair of thoracic injuries
Postoperative surveillance for complications (retained hemothorax, empyema, ARDS)

anchors.1: Fails to consider thoracic trauma; misattributes symptoms to unrelated diagnosis
anchors.2: Delayed or incomplete differential diagnosis; overlooks key features
anchors.3: Recognizes thoracic trauma as possible but omits important alternatives
anchors.4: Develops comprehensive differential including penetrating thoracic trauma and systematically rules out other causes
anchors.5: Quickly identifies penetrating thoracic trauma as leading diagnosis and articulates full differential with supporting/refuting data

anchors.1: Fails to recognize instability or need for urgent intervention
anchors.2: Recognizes urgency but delays critical actions or orders inappropriate tests
anchors.3: Initiates management but misses key steps or timing
anchors.4: Prioritizes resuscitation, diagnostics, and therapy appropriately with good timing
anchors.5: Anticipates complications, coordinates multidisciplinary care, and makes timely decisions

anchors.2: Provides information but lacks clarity or engagement
anchors.3: Communicates findings and plans clearly but incompletely
anchors.4: Clear, logical, and empathetic communication with patient and team
anchors.5: Exemplary: succinct, compassionate, anticipates information needs of team and patient

anchors.1: Lacks understanding of operative/procedural management for penetrating thoracic trauma
anchors.2: Identifies operative option but with major gaps in technique or indications
anchors.3: Describes some operative steps but with omissions in exposure, hemorrhage control, or repair
anchors.4: Completely describes thoracotomy approach, hemorrhage control, repair techniques, and common complications
anchors.5: Demonstrates mastery of thoracotomy technique, operative nuances, alternative exposures (e.g., clamshell), and perioperative considerations

anchors.1: Disrespectful, breaches confidentiality, or fails to recognize limitations
anchors.3: Maintains respect and integrity but needs prompting for self-reflection
anchors.4: Consistently respectful, accountable, receptive to feedback
anchors.5: Role model for professionalism: humility, cultural sensitivity, ethical behavior

resident_feedback_template:
StrengthsYou demonstrated strong diagnostic reasoning by recognizing massive hemothorax and identifying criteria for emergent thoracotomy. You managed resuscitation appropriately and escalated care to surgical intervention without unnecessary delay.
Areas for ImprovementWork on refining assessment of wound trajectory and intraoperative management steps, particularly when injuries involve pulmonary or cardiac structures. Further development of postoperative planning and complication anticipation will strengthen your performance.
Suggested Reading Topics- Indications and techniques for Emergency Department Thoracotomy (SCORE)- Management of Penetrating Thoracic Trauma (ACS/ASE Review Manual)- Postoperative complications of thoracic trauma (retained hemothorax, empyema, ARDS)
